sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Poor little Barbara, &c.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Yet, deareſt Barbara, look all through the nation,
Care, ſoon or late, my love, is ev'ry man's lot.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Sorrow and melancholy, grief and vexation,
When we are young and jolly, ſoon is forgot.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: When we grow old, love! then what will you ſay?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Tattle to you, love,
And prattle to you, love,
And laugh your grief and care away.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Sweet little Barbara, &c.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Poor little Barbara, &c.

sp.speaker: ARMSTRONG.
sp.p: GO to—I tell thee, Orſon, (as I have told thee more than once) thou art too ſanguinary.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: And, I tell you, Captain Armſtrong—but always under favour, you being our leader—you are too humane.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Humanity is ſcarcely counted a fault: if ſo, 'tis a fault on the right ſide.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Umph! perhaps not with us. We are robbers.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: And why ſhould robbers lack humanity? They who plunder moſt reſpect it as a virtue, and make a ſhew on't to gild their vices. Lawyers, Phyſicians, Placemen, all—all plunder and ſlay, but all pretend to humanity.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: They are Regulars, and plunder by licence.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Then let us Quacks ſet the regulars a better example.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: This humanity, Captain, is a high horſe you are ever beſtride upon. Some day, mark my word, he'll fling you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Cruelty is a more dangerous beaſt:—When the rider's thrown, his brains are kick'd out, and no one pities him.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Like enough; but your tough horſeman, who ventures boldly, is never diſmounted. When I am engaged in a deſperate chace, (as we are, Captain,) I ſtick at nothing. I hate milk ſops.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: And love mutiny. Take heed, Orſon, I have before caution'd you not to glance at me.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: I ſay nothing: but if ſome eſcape to inform againſt us, whom we have rob'd, 'tis none of my fault. Dead men tell no tales.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Wretch! Speak that again, and you ſhall tell none. holds a carbine to his head

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Flaſh away!—I don't fear death.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: More ſhame for thee; for thou art unfit to meet it.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: I know my trade. I ſet powder, ball, and rope, at defiance.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Brute! You miſtake headſtrong inſenſibility for courage. Do not miſtake my horror of it for cowardice: for I, who ſhudder at cruelty, will fell your boldneſs to the earth, when I ſee you practiſe it. Submit.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: I do. I know not what 'tis, but I have told you, often, there is ſomething about you awes me. I cannot tell—I could kill twenty to your one.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: There 'tis.—Thou wouldſt dart upon the weak unguarded man, like a tyger. A ferocious animal, whether crawling or erect, ever ſlinks from fair oppoſition.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: My courage was never yet doubted, Captain.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Your nerves, fool. Thou art a mere machine. Could I but give it motion, I would take an oak from the foreſt, here, clap a flint into it for heart, and make as bold a fellow as thou art. Liſten to my orders.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: I obey.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Get thee to our den. Put on thy diſguiſe —then hie thee to the market town for proviſion, for our company. Here—Here is part of the ſpoil we took yeſter-night: ſee you bring an honeſt account of what you lay out. giving Money

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: My honour!—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Well, I do not doubt thee, here. Our profeſſion is ſingular; its followers do not cheat one another. You will not be back till duſk. See you fall not on any poor ſtraggling peaſant, as you return.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: I would fain encounter the ſolitary man, who is ſometimes wandering by night about the foreſt. He is rich.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Not for your life. 'Tis Sir Edward Mortimer, the head keeper. Touch him not; 'tis too near home. Beſides, he is no object for plunder. I have watch'd him, at midnight, ſtealing from his lodge, to wander like one crazed. He is good, too, to the poor; and ſhould walk unmoleſted by Charity's charter. 'Twere pity that he who adminiſters to neceſſity, all day, ſhould be rifled by neceſſity at night. An thou ſhouldſt meet him, I charge thee ſpare him.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: I muſt, if it be your order. This ſparing doctrine will go nigh, at laſt, to ſtarve all the thieves. When a man takes to the trade of a wolf, he ſhould not go like a lamb to his buſineſs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: This fellow is a downright villain: Harden'd and relentleſs. I have felt, in my penury, the world trample on me. It has driven me to take that, deſperately, which wanting I ſhould ſtarve. Death! my ſpirit cannot brook to ſee a ſleek knave walk negligently by his fellow in miſery, and ſuffer him to rot. I will wrench that comfort from him which he will not beſtow.—But nature puts a bar:—Let him adminiſter to my wants, and paſs on:—I have done with him.

lg.l: When the Robber his victim has noted,
When the Free-booter darts on his prey,
Let humanity ſpare the devoted;
Let Mercy forbid him to ſlay.
Since my hope is by penury blighted,
My ſword muſt the traveller daunt;
I will ſnatch from the rich man, benighted,
The gold he denies to my want.
But the victim when, once, I have noted,
At my foot, when I look on my prey,
Let Humanity ſpare the devoted;
Let mercy forbid me to ſlay.

div.head: SCENE II. The Hall in SIR EDWARD MORTIMER's Lodge.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, buſineſs muſt be minded:—but he ſtays
A tedious time, methinks.—You fellow!

div.stage: To a ſervant croſſing the hall.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Where is Sir Triſtful? Where's Don Melancholy?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Who, ſir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My brother, knave, Sir Edward Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He was with you, but now, ſir

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you;—
That's information. Louts, and ſerving-men,
Can never parley ſtraight. I met a fellow,
Here, in my way acroſs the heath,—a Hind—
And aſk'd how far to Lymington: I look'd
The anſwer would have bolted from his chops,
Bounce, like a pellet from a popgun.—No:—
He ſtared, and ſcratch'd his empty head, and cried,
"Where do you come from?"—Who brought in my luggage?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: It was not I, ſir,

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: There!—They never can!
Go to your maſter; pray him to diſpatch
His houſhold-work:—tell him I hate fat Folios.
Plague! when I croſs the country, here, to ſee him,
He leaves me ram'd into an elbow chair,
With a huge, heavy book, that makes me nod,
Then tumbles on my toes. Tell him, do'ſt hear,
Captain Fitzharding's company has tired me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Whoſe company?—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My own, knave.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: A book to me's a ſovereign Narcotick;
A lump of opium; every line a doſe.
Edward is all deep reading, and black letter;
He ſhews it in his very chin. H • ſpeaks
Mere Dictionary; and he pores on pages
That gives plain men the head-ach. "Scarce, and curious,"
Are baits his learning nibbles at. His brain
Is cram'd with mouldy volumes, cramp, and uſeleſs,
Like a librarian's lumber-room.—Poor fellow!
Grief will do much!—well! ſome it drives to reading,
And ſome to drinking;—'twill do much!—this trial—
A fool to fret ſo for't! his honour's clear.
Tut! I'm a ſoldier—know what honour is.
Had I been ſlander'd, and a fair Court martial
Cleanſed me from calumny, as white as ſnow,
I had ne'er moped, and fumed, and winced, and kick'd,
But ſat down heart-whole. Plague upon't! this houſe
Appears the very cave of melancholy.
Nay, hold, I lie:—here comes a petticoat.
Od! a rare wench! This is the beſt edition
In Edward's whole collection. Here, come hither!
Let me peruſe you.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Would you ſpeak with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Ave. child. I'm going now to read you.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: Read me!
You'll find me full of errors, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: No matter.
Come nearer, child: I cannot ſee to read
At ſuch a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: You had better, ſir,
Put on your ſpectacles.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye, there ſhe has me!
A plague upon old Time! old ſcythe and hourglaſs
Has ſet his mark upon me. Harkve, child:
You do not know me. You and I muſt have
Better acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: O, I've heard of you.
You are Sir Edward's kinſman, Sir—his brother.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye—his half brother—by the mother's ſide—
His elder brother.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: This gypſey's tongue is like her eye; I know not
Which is the ſharpeſt. Tell me what's your name.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: My name is Blanch, Sir—born, here, in the foreſt.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Sbud! I muſt be a Keeper in this foreſt. Whither art going, ſweet one?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Home, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Home!
Why is not this thy home?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: No, Sir; I live
Some half mile hence—with madam Helen, ſir.
I brought a letter from her, to Sir Edward.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Odſo, with Helen!—ſo—with her!—the object
Of my grave brother's groaning paſſion. Plague!
I would 'twere in the houſe. I do not like
Your rheumatick, October aſſignations,
Under an elm, by moonlight. This will end
In flannels and ſciatica. My paſſion
Is not Arcadian. Tell me, pretty one,
Shall I walk with you, home?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: No, Sir, I thank you;
It would fatigue you, ſadly.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Fatigue me!
Oons! this wild foreſt filly, here, would make me
Grandfather to Methuſaleh. Look here—
Here is a purſe of money

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: O, the father!
What will you give me any?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Gold I find
The univerſal key; the paſſe par tout.
It will unlock a foreſt maiden's heart,
As eaſy as a politician's. Here;
Here are two pieces, roſe-bud. Buy a top-knot;
Make thyſelf happy with them.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: That I will.
The poor old woman, northward of the lodge,
Lies ſick in bed. I'll take her this, poor ſoul,
To comfort her,

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Hold!—hey! the devil!—hold.
This was not meant to comfort an old woman.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why, would'nt you relieve her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Um?—yes;—
But—pſhaw? pooh, prithee—there's a time for all things.
Why tell me of her now,—of an old fool,—
Of comforting the aged, now?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: I thought
That you might have a fellow feeling, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: This little paſtoral devil's laughing at me!
Oons! come and kiſs me, jade. I am a Soldier,
And Juſtice of the Peace.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.l: Then, ſhame upon you!
Your double calling might have taught you better.
I ſee your drift now. Take your dirt again,
Good Captain-Juſtice!—Stoop for it,—and think
How an old Soldier, and a Juſtice, looks,
When he is picking up the bribes he offers,
To injure thoſe he ſhould protect;—the helpleſs,
The poor, and innocent. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I warrant me,
Could I but ſee my face now, in a glaſs,
That I look wond'rous ſheepiſh. I'm aſhamed
To pick up the two pieces.—Let them lye,—
I would not wrong the innocent;—good reaſon;—
There be ſo few that are ſo;—ſhe is honeſt;
I muſt make reparation. Odſo! Wilford!
How fares it, boy?

sp.speaker: Wilford.
sp.l: I thank you, ſir. I hope you have enjoy'd
Your health, theſe three months paſt, ſince laſt you honour'd us
With your good preſence at the lodge

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Indifferent.
Some cramps and ſhooting pains, boy. I have dropt
Some caſh here, but I am afraid to bend
To pick it up again, leſt it ſhould give me
An aukward twin • e. Stoop for it, honeſt Wilford.
There's a good lad!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Right willingly Sir. Picks up the money.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: So!
The Soldier and the Juſtice ſave their bluſhes.—
Now, carry it, I prithee, at your leiſure,
To an old goſſip, near the lodge here—northward—
I've heard of her—ſhe's bed-ridden, and ſick.
You reed not ſay who ſent you.
I conceive.
'Tis private bounty; that's true charity.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Nay, piſh!—my charity!—

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Nay, I could ſwear
'Tis not the firſt time you have offered this
In ſecret.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Um!—why no;—not quite the firſt.
But tell me, lad, how jogs the world here, eh?
In Rueful Caſtle?—What, ſome three months back,
We two were cronies. What haſt thou forgot?
Thou wert my favourite here, man.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Sir, you honour'd me
By ſaying ſo.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Tut! honour'd!—tut—a fig!
Thou art grown ſtarch and ſad. This air is catching;
Thou art infected. Harkye, Wilford, harkye!
Thou'rt a ſly rogue! What you could never tell me
Of Helen's waiting maid; the little cherry;—
Of—plague upon her name!—of—

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Blanch, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Blanch:
That's it;—the foreſt fairy.—You and I
Muſt have ſome talk about her.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Have you ſeen her?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Juſt now: juſt gone. Od! I have blunder'd horribly!
You muſt know, lad—come hither.

div.stage: They retire to the back of the ſcene.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Now for my brother, and—Ha! Wilford with him!
That imp is made my ſcourge. They whiſper too.
O! I had rather court the thunder-bolt,
To melt my bones, and pound me to a maſs,
Than ſuffer this vile canker to corrode me.
Wilford!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Who calls?—eh!—'tis ſir Edward.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Mum!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I ſeem to interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: earneſtly No, indeed.
No, on my life, ſir:—we were only talking
Of—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Hold your tongue. Oons! boy, you muſt not tell.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Not!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Not! not to be ſure:—why, 'tis a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: You ſhall know all, ſir.—'Twas a trifle— nothing—
In faith you ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: In faith you lie.
Be ſatisfied, good Edward:—'tis a toy.—
But, of all men, I would not have thee know on't.
It is a tender ſubject.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Aye, indeed!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: May not I have my ſecret? Oons! good brother,
What would you ſay, now, ſhould a meddling knave
Buſy his brains with matters, though but trivial,
Which concern you alone?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I'd have him rot:
Die piecemeal; pine; moulder in miſery.
Agent, and ſacrifice to Heaven's wrath,
When caſtigating plagues are hurl'd on man,
Stands lean, and lynx-eyed Curioſity,
Watching his neighbour's ſoul. Sleepleſs himſelf
To baniſh ſleep from others. Like a Leech
Sucking the blood-drops from a care-worn heart,
He gorges on't—then renders up his food,
To nouriſh Calumny, his foul-lung'd mate,
Who carries Rumour's trumpet; and whoſe breath,
Infecting the wide ſurface of the world,
Strikes peſtilence and blight. O, fie ont! fie!
Whip me the curious wretch from pole to pole!
Who writhes in fire, and ſcorches all around him,
A victim making victims!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: By the maſs,
'Twere a ſound whipping that, from pole to pole!
From conſtable to conſtable might ſerve.
E'en you yourſelf were like to prove, but now,
This Leech, that's yoke-fellow, you ſay, to Scandal,
The bad-breath'd trumpeter.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Your pardon, brother;
I had forgot. Wilford, I've buſineſs for you.
Wait for me—aye—an hour after dinner,
Wait for me in the library.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: The library!—
I ſicken at the ſound. aſide. Wait there for you— and—
Captain Fitzharding, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: For me. alone.

sp.speaker: Wilf
sp.p: Alone, ſir!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Yes,—begone.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I ſhall, ſir—but
If I have ever breath'd a ſyllable
That might diſpleaſe you may—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Fool! breathe no more.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I'm dumb.
I'd rather ſtep into a Lion's den
Than meet him in the library!—I go, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Brother, you are too harſh with that poor boy.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Brother, a man muſt rule his family
In his own way.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, well, well—Don't be touchy.
I ſpeak not to offend: I only ſpeak
On a friend's privilege. The poor are men,
And have their feelings, brother.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: So have I!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: One of the beſt that we can ſhew, believe me,
Is mildneſs to a ſervant. Servants, brother,
Are born with fortune's yoke about their necks;
And that is galling in itſelf enough;
We ſhould not goad them under it. The maſter
Should rather cheer them in their ſervitude,
With kindly words—not too familiar neither;
But utter'd with that air which true benevolence
Imparts to dignified nobility.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Brother, your hand. You have a gentle nature—
May no miſchance e'er ruffle it, my brother!
I've known thee from my infancy, old ſoldier;
And never did I know—I do not flatter—
A heart more ſtout, more caſed with hardy manhood,
More full of milk within. Truſt me, dear friend,
If admiration of thy charity
May argue charity in the admirer,
I am not deſtitute.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: You!—I have ſeen you
Sometimes o'erflow with it.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: And what avails it?
Honour has been my theme; good will to man
My ſtudy. I have labour'd for a name
As white as mountain ſnow; dazzling, and ſpeckleſs:
Shame on't! 'tis blur'd with blots! Fate, like a mildew,
Ruins the virtuous harveſt I would reap,
And all my crop is weeds.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Why, how now, brother!
This is all ſpleen. You mope yourſelf too much,
In this dull foreſt, here. Twenty blue devils
Are dancing jigs, and hornpipes, in your brains.
Fie, fie! be more a man.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, I have done.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Come, what's for dinner? Od! I mean to eat
Abundantly.

sp.speaker: Mort
sp.l: I know not, brother. Honeſt Winterton
Will tell you all.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What he! old Adam! he!
My merry buck of Paradiſe?—Odſo!:
I have not ſeen him. Well, he ſhall produce
A flaggon of the beſt; and, after dinner,
We will be jovial▪ Come, come, rouſe you, man!
I came on purpoſe, thirty miles from home,
To jog your ſpirits. Prithee, now, be gay!
And, prithee, too, be kind to my young favourite!
To Wilford there.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, well; I hope I have been.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: No doubt, in actions:—but in words and looks —
A rugged look's a damper to a greenhorn.
I watch'd him, now, when you frown'd angerly:
And he betray'd—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Betray'd!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Ten thouſand fears.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: The poor devil couldn't ſhew more ſcared
Had you e'en held a piſtol to his head.
Why hey-day! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Brother I —
Queſtion me not; my nerves are aſpin-like;
The ſlighteſt breath will ſhake 'em. Come, good brother.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: You'll promiſe to be gay?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I'll do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Why that's well ſaid! A man can do no more.
Od! I believe my ratling talk has given you
A ſtir already.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: That it has indeed!
Come, brother!

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Are you he that wiſh to enter in my ſervice?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Yes, ſo pleaſe you, Madam Helen, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Why, I have ſeen you in the foreſt— at Rawbold's cottage. He is your father, as I think.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Yes, ſo pleaſe you, Madam; for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: I fear me you may well ſay that. Your father, as I have heard, bears an ill name, in the foreſt.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Alas! madam he is obliged to bear it— for want of a better. We are all famiſh'd, madam: and the naked and hungry have ſeldom many friends to ſpeak well of them.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: If I ſhould hire thee, who will give thee a character?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: My father, madam.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Why ſirrah, he has none of his own.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: The more fatherly in him, madam, to give his ſon what he has need of, for himſelf. But a knave is often applied to, to vouch for a good ſervant's honeſty. I will ſerve you as faithfully as your laſt footman; who, I have heard, ran away this morning.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Truly, he did ſo.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: I was told on't, ſome half hour ago; and ran, hungrily, hither, to offer myſelf. So, pleaſe you, let not poverty ſtand in the way of my preferment.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Should I entertain you, what could you do to make yourſelf uſeful?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Any thing. I can wire hares, ſnare partridges, ſhoot a buck, and ſmuggle brandy, for you, madam.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Fie on you, knave! 'Twere fitter to turn you over to the Verderors of the foreſt, for puniſhment, than to encourage you in ſuch practices.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: I would practiſe any thing better, that might get me bread. I would ſcrape trenchers, fill buckets, and carry a meſſage. What can a man do! He can't ſtarve.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Well, ſirrah, to ſnatch thee from evil, I care not if I make trial of thee?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: No! will you?

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Nineteen in twenty might queſtion my prudence for this:—but, whatever loſs I may ſuffer from thy roguery, the thought of having open'd a path to lead a needy wanderer back to virtue, will more than repay me.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: O, bleſs you, lady! If I do not prove virtuous never truſt in man more. I am overjoy'd!

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Get thee to the kitchen. You will find a lively there will ſuit you.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: A livery! O, the father! Virtuous and a livery, all in a few ſeconds! Heaven bleſs you!

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Well, get you to your work.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I go, madam. If I break any thing to day, beſeech you let it go for nothing; for joy makes my hand tremble. Should you want me pleaſe to cry Samſon, and I am with you in a twinkling. Heaven bleſs you! Here's fortune▪ Exit.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: Blanch ſtays a tedious time. Heaven ſend Mortimer's health be not worſe! He is ſadly altered ſince we came to the foreſt. I dream'd laſt night, of the fire he ſaved me from; and I ſaw him, all freſh, in manly bloom, bearing me through the flames, even as it once happened.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: How now, wench! You have almoſt tired my patience.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: And my own legs, madam. If the old faotman had not made ſo much uſe of his, by running away, they might have ſpared mine.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Inform me of Sir Edward Mortimer.
Haſt ſeen him?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Yes, I have, madam.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Say; tell me;
How look'd he? how's his health? is he in ſpirits?
What ſaid he, Blanch? Will he be here to day?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: A little breath, madam, and I will anſwer all duly.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: O! fie up in thee, wench!
Theſe interrogatories ſhould be anſwered
Quicker than breath can utter them.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: That's impoſſible, lady.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Thou would'ſt not ſay ſo hadſt thou ever lov'd.
Love has a fleeter meſſenger than ſpeech,
To tell love's meaning. His expreſſes poſt
Upon the orbs of viſion, ere the tongue
Can ſhape them into words. A lover's look
Is his heart's Mercury. O! the Eye's eloquence,
Twin-born with thought, outſtrips the tardy voice,
Far ſwifter than the nimble lightning's flaſh
The ſluggiſh thunder-peal that follows it.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I am not ſkill'd in eye-talking, madam. I have been uſed to let my diſcourſe ride upon my tongue, and, I have been told, 'twill trot at a good round pace upon occaſion.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Then let it gallop, now, beſeech you, wench,
And bring me news of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Then, madam, I ſaw Sir Edward in his library: and deliver'd your letter. He will be here either in the evening, or on the morrow: 'tis uncertain which—for his brother, Capt. Fitzharding, is arrived on a viſit to him.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Is he?—well, that may ſomewhat raiſe his ſpirits.
That ſoldier has a pleaſant, harmleſs mind.
Mirth gilds his age, and ſits upon his brow
Like ſun in winter. I ne'er ſaw a man
More cheerful in decline, more laughter-loving,
More gay, and frolickſome.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Frolickſome enough, if you knew all— but not ſo harmleſs. aſide

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.p: He'll ſcarce be here to night.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Who? Sir Edward? Haply not, madam: but his letter may chance to ſpecify further particulars.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: His letter! Has he written?—fie upon thee!
Why didſt not give it me, at once? Where is it?
Thou art turn'd dreamer, wench!—Come, quickly.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You talk'd to me ſo much of reading eyes, madam, that I e'en forgot the letter. Here it is.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Come to me, ſhortly, in my cabinet:
I'll read it there.—I am almoſt unfit
To open it. I ne'er receive his letters
But my hand trembles. Well, I know 'tis ſilly,
And yet I cannot help it. I will ring;
Then come to me, good Blanch—not yet. My Mortimer,
Now for your letter!Exit.

sp.speaker: Blanch
sp.p: I would they were wedded once, and all this trembling would be over. I am told your married lady's feelings are little rouſed in reading letters from a huſband.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: This ſudden turn of fortune might puff ſome men up with pride. I have look'd in the glaſs already:—and if ever man look'd braver in a glaſs than I, I know nothing of finery.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Hey day! who have we here?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh, lord! this is the maid.—I mean the waiting-woman. I warrant we ſhall be rare company, in a long winter's evening.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why, who are you?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'm your fellow-ſervant:—the new comer. The laſt footman caſt his ſkin in the pantry this morning, and I have crept into it.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why, ſure, it cannot be!—Now I look upon you again, you are Samſon Rawbold—old Rawbold's ſon, of the foreſt here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The ſame; I am not like ſome upſtarts; When I am proſperous, I do not turn my back on my poor relations.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What, has my lady hired thee?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: She has taken me, like a pad nag, upon trial.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I ſuſpect you will play her a jade's trick, and ſtumble in your probation. You have been caught tripping, ere now.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: An I do not give content 'tis none of my fault. A man's qualities cannot come out all at once. I wiſh you would teach me a little how to lay a cloth.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You are well qualified for your office truly, not to know that!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: To ſay truth, we had little practice that way at home. We ſtood not upon forms. We had ſometimes no cloth for a dinner.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: And, ſometimes, no dinner for a cloth.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Juſt ſo. We had little order in our family.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Well, I will inſtruct you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That's kind. I will be grateful. They tell me I have learnt nothing but wickedneſs yet: but I will inſtruct you in any thing I know, in return.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: There I have no mind to become your ſcholar. But be ſteady in your ſervice, and you may outlive your beggary, and grow into reſpect.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Nay, an riches rain upon me, reſpect will grow of courſe. I never knew a rich man yet who wanted followers to pull off their caps to him.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: A traveller ſtopt at a widow's gate;
She kept an Inn, and he wanted to bait;—
But the landlady ſlighted her gueſt:
For when Nature was making an ugly race,
She certainly moulded this traveller's face
As a ſample for all the reſt.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The chamber-maid's ſides they were ready to crack,
When ſhe ſaw his queer noſe, and the hump at his back;—
A hump is'nt handſome, no doubt—
And though 'tis confeſs'd, that the prejudice goes,
Very ſtrongly, in favour of wearing a noſe,
Yet a noſe ſhould'nt look like a ſnout.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: A bag full of gold on the table he laid—
'T had a wond'rous effect on the widow and maid!
And they quickly grew marvellous civil.
The money immediately alter'd the caſe;
They were charm'd with his hump, and his ſnout, and his face,
Tho' he ſtill might have frighted the devil.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: He paid like a prince—gave the widow a ſmack—
Then ſtop'd on his horſe, at the door, like a ſack;
While the landlady, touching the chink,
Cried—"Sir, ſhould you travel this country again,
"I heartily hope that the ſweeteſt of men
"Will ſtop at the widow's to drink"Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.—The LIBRARY.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I would Sir Edward were come! The dread of a fearful encounter is, often, as terrible as the encounter itſelf. Yet my encounters with him, of late, are no trifles. Some few hours back, in this very room, he held a loaded piſtol within an inch of my brains. Well, that was paſſion—he threw it from him on the inſtant, and—eh!—He's coming.— No. The old wainſcot cracks, and frightens me out of my wits: and, I verily believe, the great folio dropt on my head, juſt now, from the ſhelf, on purpoſe to encreaſe my terrors.

div.stage: Enter Sir EDWARD MORTIMER, at one door of the Library, which he locks after him. WILFORD turns round on hearing him ſhut it.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What's that?—'Tis he himſelf! Mercy on me! he has lock'd the door!—What is going to become of me!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Wilford!—Is no one in the picture-gallery?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: No—not a ſoul, Sir—Not a human ſoul.—
None within hearing, if I were to bawl
Ever ſo loud.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Lock yonder door.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: The door, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Do as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: What, Sir? Lock— Mortimer waves with his hand
I ſhall, Sir. going to the door and locking it
His face has little anger in it, neither:
'Tis rather mark'd with ſorrow, and diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Wilford, approach me.—What am I to ſay
For aiming at your life!—Do you not ſcorn me,
Deſpiſe me for it?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I! Oh, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: You muſt.
For I am ſingled from the herd of men,
A vile, heart-broken wretch!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed, Sir,
You deeply wrong yourſelf. Your equal's love,
The poor man's prayer, the orphan's tear of gratitude,
All follow you:—and I!—I owe you all!
I am moſt bound to bleſs you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Mark me, Wilford.—
I know the value of the orphan's tear,
The poor man's prayer, reſpect from the reſpected;
I feel to merit theſe, and to obtain them,
Is to taſte here, below, that thrilling cordial
Which the remunerating Angel draws,
From the eternal fountain of delight,
To pour on bleſſed ſouls, that enter heaven.
I feel this:—I!—How muſt my nature, then,
Revolt at him who ſeeks to ſtain his hand,
In human blood?—and yet it ſeems, this day,
I ſought your life.—O! I have ſuffer'd madneſs—
None know my tortures—pangs!—but I can end them:
End them as far as appertains to thee.—
I have reſolv'd it.—Hell-born ſtruggles tear me!
But I have ponder'd on't,—and I muſt truſt thee.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Your confidence ſhall not be—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You muſt ſwear.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Swear, Sir!—will nothing but an oath, then—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Liſten.
May all the ills that wait on frail humanity
Be doubled on your head, if you diſcloſe
My fatal ſecret! May your body turn
Moſt lazar-like, and loathſome; and your mind
More loathſome than your body! May thoſe fiends
Who ſtrangle babes, for very wantonneſs,
Shrink back, and ſhudder at your monſtrous crimes,
And, ſhrinking, curſe you! Palſies ſtrike your youth!
And the ſharp terrors of a guilty mind
Poiſon your aged days; while all your nights,
As on the earth you lay your houſeleſs head,
Out-horror horror! May you quit the world
Abhor'd, ſelf-hated, hopeleſs for the next,
Your life a burthen, and your death a fear!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: For mercy's ſake, forbear! you terrify me!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Hope this may fall upon thee;—Swear thou hopeſt it,
By every attribute which heaven, earth, hell,
Can lend, to bind, and ſtrengthen conjuration,
If thou betray'ſt me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Well I— heſitating.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: No retreating!

sp.speaker: Wilf.

l.hi: I ſwear, by all the ties that bind a man,

sp.l: Divine, or human,—never to divulge!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Remember you have ſought this ſecret.
—Yes,
Extorted it. I have not thruſt it on you.
'Tis big with danger to you; and to me,
While I prepare to ſpeak, torment unutterable.
Know, Wilford that—damnation!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Deareſt Sir!
Collect yourſelf. This ſhakes you horribly.
You had this trembling, it is ſcarce a week,
At Madam Helen's.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: There it is.—Her Uncle!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Her uncle!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Him. She knows it not—None know it—
You are the firſt ordained to hear me ſay,
I am—his murderer.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: O, heaven!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: His aſſaſſin.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What you that—mur—the murder— I am choak'd!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Honour, thou blood—ſtain'd God! at whoſe red altar
Sit War and Homicide, O, to what madneſs
Will inſult drive thy votaries! By heaven,
In the world's range there does not breathe a man
Whoſe brutal nature I more ſtrove to ſoothe,
With long forbearance, kindneſs, courteſy,
Than his who fell by me. But he diſgraced me,
Stain'd me,—oh, death, and ſhame!—the world look'd on,
And ſaw this ſinewy ſavage ſtrike me down;
Rain blows upon me, drag me to and fro,
On the baſe earth, like carrion, Deſperation,
In every fibre of my frame, cried vengeance!
I left the room, which he had quitted. Chance
(Curſe on the chance!) while boiling with my wrongs,
Thruſt me againſt him, darkling, in the ſtreet:—
I ſtab'd him to the heart:—and my oppreſſor
Roll'd, lifeleſs, at my foot.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Oh! mercy on me!
How could this deed be cover'd!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Would you think it?
E'en at the moment when I gave the blow,
Butcher'd a fellow-creature in the dark,
I had all good mens love. But my diſgrace,
And my opponent's death, thus link'd with it,
Demanded notice of the magiſtracy.
They ſummon'd me, as friend would ſummon friend,
To acts of import, and communication.
We met: and 'twas reſolved, to ſtifle rumour,
To put me on my trial. No accuſer,
No evidence appeared, to urge it on.—
'Twas meant to clear my fame.—How clear it, then?
How cover it? you ſay.—Why, by a Lie:
Guilt's offspring, and its guard. I taught this breaſt,
Which Truth once made her throne, to forge a lie;
This tongue to utter it.—Rounded a tale,
Smooth as a Seraph's ſong from Satan's mouth;
So well compacted, that the o'er throng'd court
Diſturb'd cool juſtice, in her judgment-ſeat,
By ſhouting "Innocence!" ere I had finiſh'd.
The Court enlarged me; and the giddy rabble
Bore me, in triumph, home. Aye!—look upon me!—
I know thy ſight aches at me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Heaven forgive me!
I think I love you ſtill:—but I am young;
I know not what to ſay:—it may be wrong.—
Indeed I pity you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I diſdain all pity.—
I aſk no conſolation. Idle boy!
Think'ſt thou that this compulſive confidence
Was given to move thy pity?—Love of fame
(For ſtill I cling to it) has urged me, thus,
To quaſh thy curious miſchief in its birth.
Hurt honour, in an evil, curſed hour,
Drove me to murder—lying:—'twould again.
My honeſty,—ſweet peace of mind,—all, all!
Are barter'd for a name. I will maintain it.
Should ſlander whiſper o'er my ſepulchre,
And my ſoul's agency ſurvive in death,
I could embody it with heaven's lightning,
And the hot ſhaft of my inſulted ſpirit
Should ſtrike the blaſter of my memory
Dead in the church-yard. Boy, I would not kill thee:
Thy raſhneſs and diſcernment threaten'd danger:
To check them there was no way left but this:
Save one—your death:—you ſhall not be my victim.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: My death! What take my life?—My life! to prop
This empty honour.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Empty! Groveling fool!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I am your ſervant, Sir: child of your bounty;
And know my obligation. I have been
Too curious, haply; 'tis the fault of youth.
I ne'er meant injury: if it would ſerve you,
I would lay down my life; I'd give it freely:—
Could you, then, have the heart to rob me of it?
You could not;—ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: You dare not.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Dare not!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Some hours ago you durſt not. Paſſion moved you;
Reflection interpoſed, and held your arm.
But, ſhould reflection prompt you to attempt it,
My innocence would give me ſtrength to ſtruggle,
And wreſt the murderous weapon from your hand.
How would you look to find a peaſant boy
Return the knife you level'd at his heart;
And aſk you which in heaven would ſhew the beſt,
A rich man's honour, or a poor man's honeſty?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: 'Tis plain I dare not take your life. To ſpare it,
I have endanger'd mine. But dread my power;—
You know not its extent. Be warn'd in time:
Trifle not with my feelings. Liſten, Sir!
Myriads of engines, which my ſecret working
Can rouſe to action, now encircle you.
I ſpeak not vaguely. You have heard my principle;
Have heard, already, what it can effect:
Be cautious how you thwart it. Shun my brother;
Your ruin hangs upon a thread: Provoke me,
And it ſhall fall upon you. Dare to make
The ſlighteſt movement to awake my fears,
And the gaunt criminal, naked and ſtake-tied,
Left on the heath to bliſter in the ſun,
'Till lingering death ſhall end his agony,
Compared to thee, ſhall ſeem more enviable
Than Cherubs to the damn'd.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: O, miſery!
Diſcard me ſir! I muſt be hateful to you.
Baniſh me hence. I will be mute as death;
But let me quit your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Never.—Fool!
To buy this ſecret, you have ſold yourſelf.
Your movements, eyes, and, moſt of all, your breath,
From this time forth, are fetter'd to my will.
You have ſaid, truly: you are hateful to me:
Yet you ſhall feel my bounty:—that ſhall flow,
And ſwell your fortunes; but my inmoſt ſoul
Will yearn with loathing, when—hark! ſome one knocks!
Open the door.

div.stage: Wilford opens the door, and Winterton comes in.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: How now, Winterton?
Did you knock more than once? Speak—did you liſten—
—I mean, good Adam, did you wait?—Aye, wait
Long at the door, here?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Bleſs your honour! no.
You are too good to let the old man wait.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: What, then, our talk, here—Wilford's here and mine—
Did not detain you at the door?—Ha!—did it?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Not half-a-ſecond.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Oh!—well, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Capt. Fitzharding, Sir, entreats your company.
I've placed another flaggon on the table.
Your worſhip knows it.—Number thirty-five:—
The ſupernaculum.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Well, well.—I come.
What, has he been alone?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: No—I've been with him.
Od! he's a merry man! and does ſo jeſt!
He calls me firſt of men, 'cauſe my name's Adam.
Well! 'tis exceeding pleaſant, by Sr. Thomas!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Come, Adam; I'll attend the Captain. —Wilford,
What I have juſt now given you in charge,
Be ſure to keep faſt lock'd. I ſhall be angry,—
Be very angry, if I find you careleſs.
Follow me, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p:
This houſe is no houſe for me. Fly I will, I am reſolved:—but whither? His threats ſtrike terror into me; and were I to reach the pole, I doubt whether I ſhould elude his graſp. But to live here a ſlave—ſlave to his fears,—his jealouſies! Night's coming on. Darkneſs be my friend! for I will forth
inſtantly. The thought of my innocence will cheer me as I wander through the gloom. Oh! when guilty Ambition writhes upon his couch, why ſhould bare-foot Integrity repine, though his ſweet ſleep be canopied with a ragged hovel!Exit.

div.head: SCENE V.—The inſide of an Abbey, in ruins. Part of it converted into an habitation for Robbers. Various entrances to their apartment, through the broken arches of the building, &c. &c.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Well, ſirrah! have you been upon the ſcout? Are any of our gang returning?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Judith! not a ſoul.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: The rogues tarry thus to fret me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, indeed, Judith, the credit of your cookery is loſt among thieves. They never come punctual to their meals.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: No tidings of Orſon yet, from the market town?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I have ſeen nothing of him,

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Brat! thou doſt never bring me good news.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Judith, you are ever ſo croſs with me!

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: That wretch Orſon ſlights my love of late. Hence, you hemp-ſeed, hence! Get to the broken porch of the abbey, and watch. 'Tis all you are good for.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You know I am but young yet, Judith, but with good inſtructions, I may be a robber in time.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Away, you imp! you will never reach ſuch preferment. A whiſtle without. So! I hear ſome of our party Whiſtle again. The Boy puts his fingers in his mouth, and whiſtles in anſwer.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Why muſt you keep your noiſe, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Nay, Judith, 'tis one of the firſt ſteps we boys learn in the profeſſion. I ſhall ne'er come to good, if you check me ſo. Huzza! here come two!

div.stage: Enter two Robbers, through the broken part of the Scene.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: So! you have found your road at laſt. A murrain light upon you! is it thus you keep your hours!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: What, hag, ever at this trade! Ever grumbling?

sp.speaker: Jub.
sp.p: I have reaſon. I toil to no credit; I watch with no thanks. I trim up the table for your return, and no one returns in due time to notice my induſtry. Your meat is ſcorch'd to cinders. Rogues, would it were poiſon for you!

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: How the fury raves! Here, take my carbine; 'twas levell'd, ſome half hour ſince, at a traveller's head.

sp.speaker: Jub.
sp.p: Hah, hah, hah! Rare! Didſt ſhoot him?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Shoot him? No. This devil in petticoats thinks no more of ſlaying a man, than killing a cockchafer. I never knew a woman turn to miſchief, that ſhe did not outdo a man, clean.

sp.speaker: Jub.
sp.p: Did any of you meet Orſon on your way?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Aye, there the hand points. When that fellow is abroad you are more ſavage than cuſtomary; and that is needleſs.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: None of our comrades come yet? They will be finely ſoak'd.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Aye, the rain pours like a ſpout upon the ruins of the old abbey wall here.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I'm glad on't. May it drench them, and breed agues! 'twill teach them to keep time.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Peace! thou abominable railer. A man had better dwell in purgatory, than have thee in his habitation.—Peace, devil! or I'll make thee repent.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: You! 'tis as much as thy life is worth to move my ſpleen.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: What, you will ſet Orſon, your champion, upon me?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Coward! he ſhould not diſgrace himſelf with chaſtiſing thee.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Death and thunder!—

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Aye, attack a woman, do! it ſuits your hen-hearted valour. Aſſault a woman!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Well—paſſion hurried roe. But I have a reſpect for the ſoft ſex, and am cool again. Come, Judith, be friends.—Nay, come, do; and I will give thee a farthingale, I took from a lawyer's widow.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: You ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Well—I— Hark!

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Soft! I think I hear the foot of a comrade.

div.head: MUSICAL DIALOGUE AND CHORUS.
div.l: Liſten! No; it is the owl,
That hoots upon the mould'ring tow'r.
Hark! the rain beats, the night is foul!
Our comrades ſtay beyond their hour.
All's huſh'd around the abbey wall.—
Soft! Now I hear the robber's call!
And here another; and here another!
Who comes! A brother. Who comes?
Now they all come pouring in;
We're here! and here, and here, and here!
Then meet to drain the flowing bowl!

stage.hi: At different periods of the Muſick, the Robbers enter, through various parts of Ruins, in groups.

div.stage: Enter ORSON, with Luggage on his Back, as if return'd from the Market.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Rob.
sp.p: See! hither comes Orſon at laſt. He walks in like Plenty, with proviſion on his ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: O, Orſon!—why did'ſt tarry, Orſon? I began to fear. Thou art cold and damp. Let me wring the wet from thy cloaths. O! my heart leaps to ſee hee.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Mark how this ſhe-bear hugs her bruin!

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Stand off! This hamper has been weariſome enough. I want not thee on my neck.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Villain! 'tis thus you ever uſe me. I can revenge:—I can—do not, dear Orſon! do not treat me thus.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Let a man be ever ſo ſweet temper'd, he will meet ſomewhat to ſour it. I have been vex'd to madneſs.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: How now, Orſon, what has vex'd thee now?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: A prize has ſlipt through my fingers.

sp.speaker: 3d Rob.
sp.p: Aye! marry, how?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: I met a ſtraggling knave on foot, and the rogue reſiſted. He had the face to tell me that he was thruſt on the world to ſeek his fortune; and that the little he had about him was his all. Plague on the proviſion at my back! I had no time to rifle him: —but I have ſpoil'd him for fortune ſeeking, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Why I beat him to the ground. Whether he will e'er get up again the next paſſenger may diſcover.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! O, brave,! That's my valiant Orſon!

sp.speaker: 3d. Rob.
sp.p: Orſon, you are ever diſobeying our Captain's order. You are too remorſeleſs and bloody.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Take heed, then, how you move my anger, by telling me on't. The affair is mine—I will anſwer to the conſequence.

sp.speaker: 4th. Rob.
sp.p: I hear our Captain's ſignal. Here he comes. Ha!—he is leading one who ſeems wounded.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Gently, good fellow! come, keep a good heart!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: You are very kind. I had breathed my laſt, but for your care. Whither have you led me?

sp.speaker: 4th. Rob.
sp.p: Where you will be well treated, youngſter. You are now among as honourable a knot of men as ever cried "ſtand" to a traveller.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: How: among robbers!

sp.speaker: 4th. Rob.
sp.p: Why ſo the law's cant calls us gentlemen who live at large.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: So! for what am I reſerved!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Fear nothing. You are ſafe in this aſylum. Judith, lead him in. See ſome of my linen ready, and look to his wound.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I do not like the office. You are ever at theſe tricks. 'Twill ruin us in the end. What have we to do with charity?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Turbulent wretch! obey me.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall. Come, fellow, ſince it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Anon, I'll viſit you myſelf, lad.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you! whate'er becomes of my life—and faith, I am almoſt weary on't—I am bound to your charity. Gently, I pray you—my wound pains. Gently!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I would I knew which of you had done this.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Rob.
sp.p: Wdy what's the matter, Captain?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Cruelty is the matter. Had not accident led me to the ſpot where he lay, you poor boy had bled to death. I learn'd his ſtory, partly, from him,
on the way: and know how baſely he has been handled by one of you. Well, time muſt diſcover him: for he, who had brutality enough to commit the action, can ſcarcely have courage enough to confeſs it.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Courage, Captain, is a quality, I take it, little wanted by any here. What ſignify words—I did it.

sp.speaker: Arm▪
sp.p: I ſuſpected thee, Orſon. 'Tis ſcarce an hour ſince he, whom thou haſt wounded, quitted the ſervice of Sir Edward Mortimer, in the foreſt, here; and enquiry will doubtleſs be made.

sp.speaker: 2d. Rob.
sp.p: Nay then we are diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Now, mark what thou haſt done. Thou haſt endanger • d the ſafety of our party; thou haſt broke my order (tis not the firſt time, by many) in attacking a paſſenger:—and what paſſenger? One whoſe unhappy caſe ſhould have claim'd thy pity. He told you he had diſpleaſed his maſter—left the houſe of comfort, and with his ſcanty pittance, was wandering round the world to mend his fortune. Like a butcher, you ſtruck the forlorn boy to the earth, and left him to languiſh in the foreſt. Would any of our brave comrades have done this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: —None! None!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Comrades, in this caſe, my voice is ſingle. But if it have any weight, this brute, this Orſon, ſhall be thruſt from our community, which he has diſgraced. Let it not be ſaid, brothers, while want drives us to plunder, that wantonneſs prompts us to butchery.

sp.speaker: Robbers.
sp.p: O brave Captain! away with him!

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: You had better ponder on't, ere you provoke me.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Raſcal! do you mutter threats. You cannot terrify us. Our calling teems with danger—we are not to be daunted by the treachery of an informer. We defy you. Go. Yon dare not hurt us. You dare not ſacrifice ſo many brave, and gallant fellows, to your revenge, and proclaim yourſelf ſcoundrel. Begone.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Well, if I muſt, I muſt. I was always a friend to you all: but if you are bent on turning me out—why—fare you well.

sp.speaker: Robbers.
sp.p: Aye, aye—Away, away.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Farewell then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Come, comrades—Think no more of this. Let us drown the choler we have felt in wine and revelry.

div.head: FINALE.
div.l: Ere theſe Abbey walls had crumbled;
Still the ruins boaſt good cheer,
Though long ago the cloyſters tumbled.
Ding dong! ding dong! to the bald-pated monk!
And all go to bed moſt religiouſly drunk.
Peace to the good fat Friar's ſoul!
Huzza! Huzza! we'll drink and we'll ſing!

div.head: SCENE I. WINTERTON's Room, in SIR EDWARD MORTIMER's Lodge.
div.stage: SAMSON and BLANCH, diſcover'd, at a Table, with Bottle and Glaſſes.

sp.speaker: BLANCH.
sp.p: SAMSON, you muſt drink no more.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: One more glaſs, Miſtreſs Blanch, and I ſhall be better company. 'Twill make me loving.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Nay, then, you ſhall not have a drop.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: I will:—and ſo ſhall you too. filling the glaſs Who knows but it may make you the ſame?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You are wond'rous familiar, Mr Lout.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: I would not willingly offend. I will endeavour at more reſpect. My humble duty to you. drinks.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I would counſel you to be cautious of drinking, Samſon. Conſider where you are. We are now, remember, in Sir Edward Mortimer's Lodge.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: In the Butler's room;—where drinking has always a privilege. fills.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What, another!

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Do not fear. 'Twill not make me familiar again. My lowly reſpects to yon. drinks. This ſame old Winterton's wine has a marvellous choice flavour. I wonder whether 'twas ſmuggled.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Should you totter with this, now, in the morning, 'twould go nigh to ſhake your office to the foundation, before night. My Lady would never pardon you.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: 'Twould be hard to turn me adrift, for getting drunk, on the ſecond day of my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Truly, I think 'twould be reaſon ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: 'Twould not be giving a man a fair trial. How ſhould ſhe know but I intend to be ſober for a year after?

sp.speaker: Blanch,
sp.p: How ſhould ſhe know, indeed! or any one elſe, who has heard of your former rogueries.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Well, the worſt fault I had was being a ſportſman.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: A ſportſman! out on you, rogue! you were a poacher.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Aye, ſo the rich nick-name us poor brothers of the field; and lay us by the heels when we do that for hunger which they practiſe for amuſement. Cannot I move you to take a thimble-full, this cold morning?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Not a drop, I

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Hark! I think I hear old Winterton coming back. By our lady, Miſtreſs Blanch, we have made a deſperate hole in the bottle, ſince he left us.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: We! why, you ſlanderous rogue, I have not taſted it.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: No—'tis not he.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: No matter; he will be back on the inſtant. Leave this idle guzzling, if you have any ſhame. Think we are attending madam Helen, in her viſit to Sir Edward, on his ſudden ſickneſs. Think, too, on the confuſion from Wilford's flight. Is it a time for you, ſo, to tipple, when the whole houſe is in diſtreſs and melancholy?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Alas! I have too tender a heart, Miſtreſs Blanch; and have need of ſomewhat, in the midſt of this ſorrow, to cheer my ſpirits

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: This wine will ſhortly give your profeſſion of amendment the lie.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Let it give me the lie: 'Tis an affront I can eaſily ſwallow. Come, a bargain—an you will take one glaſs with me, I will give over.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Well, on that condition—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Agreed— for that will juſt finiſh the bottle. fills. I will drink no health, now, but of thy giving.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Then liſten and edify.—May a man never inſult a woman with his company, when drunkenneſs has made him a brute!

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: With all my heart:—But a woman knows that man may be made a brute, when wine is clean out of the queſtion. Eh! Here comes the old man, in real earneſt.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Well, I am here again.—What madcap? —In truth, I have a world of care. Our good maſter taken ill on a ſudden. Wilford flown:—A baſe, ungrateful boy!—One that I was ſo fond of:—And to prove ſuch a profligate! I began to love the young villain like my own child. I had mark'd down the unfortunate boy, in my laſt teſtament: I had— Bleſs me! my cold is wondrous troubleſome to my eyes, this morning. Ah! 'tis a wicked world:— But old Winterton keeps a merry heart ſtill. Do I not, pretty miſtreſs Blanch?

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I hope you do, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Nay, on ſecond thought, I do not keep it; for thou haſt ſtolen it from me, tulip! ha! good ifaith!—

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—Well ifaith that is a good jeſt! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Doſt think ſo, varlet? "Thou haſt ſtolen it from me, tulip!" Well, it was; it was exceeding pleaſant, by St. Thomas! Heigho! I muſt e'en take a glaſs to conſole me. One cup to—eh! mercy on me! why the liquor has flown. Ha! the bottle has leak'd, haply.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Yes, Sir:—I crack'd that bottle, myſelf, in your abſence.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Crack'd! Why what a careleſs gooſe art thou! theſe unthrifty knaves!—ah▪ times are ſadly changed for the worſe, ſince I was a boy.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Doſt think ſo, Adam?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Queſtion any man, of my age, and he will ſay the ſame. Domeſticks never broke bottles in queen Elizabeth's time. Servants were better then— aye, marry, and the bottles were better bottles. 'Tis a degenerate world! Well; heigho!

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Why doſt ſigh thus, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: In truth, this is as heavy a day for me!—

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I hope not, Adam. Gome, come, things are not ſo bad, I warrant thee. You have long drank ſmilingly of the cup of life, Adam; and when a good man takes his potion without murmuring, Providence ſeldom leaves the bittereſt drop at the bottom. What is the matter, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Alas! nothing but evil. Theſe attacks come on our worthy maſter as thick as hail, and weaken him daily. He has been grievous ill, in the night, poor ſoul! and ne'er ſlept a wink ſince I brought him the news.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What news, good Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Why of Wilford's flight!—A reprobate! The ſhock of his baſeneſs has brought on Sir Edward's old ſymptoms.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What call you his old ſymptoms?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: The ſhivering, and trembling its, which have troubled him theſe two years. I begin to think the air of this foreſt doth nouriſh agues. I can never move him to drink enough of canary. I think, in my conſcience, I had been aguiſh myſelf, in theſe woods, had I not drank plenty of canary.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Maſs, when I am ill, this old boy ſhall be my apothecary. aſide.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Well, well, he may mend. Do not fancy the worſt, ere worſe arrives, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Nay, worſe has arrived already. Blanch. Aye! marry, how?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Wilford's villany. Sir Edward ſays, he has proofs of the blackeſt treachery againſt him.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p:
It chills my blood to think on't! I had mark'd out the boy as a boy of promiſe—A learned
boy! He had the backs of all the books in our library by heart: and now a hue and cry is after him. Mercy on me! if the wretched lad be taken, Sir Edward will bring him to the charge. We none know what 'tis yet; but time will ſhew.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: You ſurpriſe me! Wilford turn diſhoneſt! I could ſcarce have credited this; and after two years trial, too.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: O, monſtrous! to turn rogue after two years! Had it happened after two days, indeed, 'twere not to be wonder'd at.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Winterton, there is a young woman of the foreſt, would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Out on't! Theſe cottagers time their buſineſs vilely. Well, bid her come in, Simon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And, Miſtreſs Blanch, your lady would ſee you anon, in the breakfaſt parlour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: I come quickly. Be not caſt down, now, Adam; keep thy old heart merry ſtill.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Ha! in truth, I know not well, now, what would mend my ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: What think you of the kiſs I promis'd?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Ah, wag! go thy way Od! thou haſt nimble legs. Had I o'ertaken thee yeſterday—Ah! well, no matter.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p: Come, I will not leave thee comfortleſs, in theſe ſad times Here—Here is my hand, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Thou wilt ſhew me a light pair of heels again, now.

sp.speaker: Blanch
sp.p: No, in faith. Come; 'tis more than I would offer to every one. Take it.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: That I will, moſt willingly. Kiſſes her hand.

sp.speaker: Blanch.
sp.p:
Do not play the rake now, and boaſt of my favours; for I am told there is a breed of puppies will build ſtories, to a ſimple girl's prejudice, on
ſlighter encouragement than this. Be not you one of thoſe empty coxcombs, and ſo adieu, Adam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Nay, I was never given to vaunt. 'Sbud! if I had, many a tale had been told, ſixty years back, of young, luſty Adam Winterton.—Eh! why what doſt thou titter at, ſcapegrace?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: I, ſir?—Not I ſmothering a laugh.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: I had forgot this varlet. Peſtilence on't I Should this knave prate of my little gallantry, I tremble for the good name of poor Miſtreſs Blanch!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: May I come in, good your worſhip?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Aye, marry, that thou may'ſt, pretty one. —Well, though many things have declined, ſince I was a boy, female-beauty keeps its rank ſtill. I do think there be more pretty women now than there were in Queen Elizabeth's reign.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Fleſh! this is our Barbara. aſide.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Well, and what wouldſt have, ſweet one, with old Adam—Eh! by St. Thomas, why thou art ſhe I have ſeen, ere now, with Wilford.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Beſeech you, tell me where he is, ſir?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Alas, child, he's gone—flown! Eh? what —why art not well, child?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Nothing, ſir—I only—I hoped he would have called at our cottage, ere he quitted the foreſt. Is there no hope that he may come back, ſir?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: None, truly, except force bring him back. Alas, child! the boy has turn'd out naught; and juſtice is dogging him at the heels.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: What Wilford, ſit?—my poor—O, ſir, my heart is burſting! I pray you, pardon me. Had he paſs'd our cottage in his flight, I would have ran out, and follow'd him all the world over.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: To ſee what love will do! Juſt ſo did Jane Blackthorn take on for me, when Sir Marmaduke carried me to London, in the hard winter.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Beſeech you, forgive me, ſir! I only came to make enquiry, for I had heard a ſtrange tale. I would not have my ſorrows make me troubleſome to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: To me? poor wench! nay, that thou art not. I truſt, child, I never turned a deaf ear, yet, to the unfortunate. 'Tis man's office to liſten to the ſorrows of a woman, and do all he can to ſoothe them. Come, come, dry thy tears, chicken.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I look'd to have been his wife ſhortly, ſir. He was as kind a youth—And, I am ſure, he wanted not gratitude. I have heard him talk of you, as you were his father, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Did he? Ah! poor lad. Well, he had good qualities; but, alas! he is now a reprobate. Poor boy! To think, now, that he ſhould ſpeak kindly of the old man, behind his back!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Alas, this is the ſecond flight to bring unhappineſs to our poor family!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: The ſecond! How do'ſt mean, wench?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: My brother, ſir, left our cottage ſuddenly, yeſterday morning; and we have no tidings of him ſince.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Lo you, now, where he ſtands, to glad the hearts of his diſconſolate relations! Siſter Barbara, why doſt not know me?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Eh! No—Sure it can't—Brother Samſon?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Mr. Samſon—Head ſerving man to the Lady Helen, of the New Foreſt.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, the fortune! can it be! what gain'd thee ſo good a place, Samſon?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Merit. I had no intereſt to back me. Mine is a rare caſe—I was promoted on the ſcore of my virtues.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Out upon thee! thy knaveries have been the talk of the whole foreſt; and furniſh'd daily food for converſation.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Truly, then, converſation has fared better upon them than I. But my old character is laid aſide with my old jerkin. I am now exalted.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: An I have any forecaſt in deſtiny, friend, thou bidſt fair, one day, to be more exalted.— Ha! good ifaith! Come, you muſt to the kitchen, knave. I muſt thither myſelf, to give order for the day.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Muſt I return home, then, your worſhip, with no tidings?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Ah! heaven help me! what havock doth wanton Cupid make with us all! Well, tarry about the houſe, with thy brother; we may hear ſomewhat, haply, anon. Take care of thy ſiſter, knave; and mark what I have ſaid to thee.—"Thou bidſt fair one day to be more exalted." Had well, it was exceeding pleaſant, by St. Thomas!Exit.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Well, Barbara, and how fares father?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: He has done nought but chide, ſince you diſappear'd, Samſon. It has ſour'd him with us all.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Well, I will call, ſoon, and ſet all even.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Will yuo, brother?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: I will. Bid him not be caſt down. I will protect the Rawbold family.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Truly, brother, we are much in need of protection.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Do not fear. Lean upon my power. I am head of all the male domeſticks, at Madam Helen's.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, the father! of all! and how many be there, brother?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Why, truly, not ſo many as there be at the Lodge, here. But I have a boy under me, to chop wood, and draw water.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: The money we had from Sir Edward's bounty, is nearly gone in payment of the debt our father owed. You know he had ſhortly been impriſon'd, elſe.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: My ſtock is ſomewhat low, too.—But, no matter. Keep a good heart. I am now a riſing man. I will make you all comfortable.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you, Samſon!

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: In three months, I look for a quarter's wages; and then Dick ſhall have a ſhirt. I muſt now take you roundly to taſk.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Me, brother!

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Aye, marry. You would throw yourſelf away on this Wilford—who▪ as the ſtory goes, is little better than the devil's own imp.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, brother! be not ſo uncharitable. I know not what is againſt him, but he has not been heard yet. Conſider too—were all our actions, at home, to be ſifted, I fear me, we might not eſcape blameleſs.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Aye, but he, it ſeems, is falling, and we are upon the riſe; and that makes all the difference. Maſs! how gingerly men will ſift the faults of thoſe who are getting up hill in the world; and what a rough ſhake they give thoſe who are going downward!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I would not be one of thoſe ſiſters, brother.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: No,—I warrant, now, thou wouldſt marry this vagabond.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: That I would, brother. He has cheer'd me in my diſtreſs, and I would ſooner die than leave him, now he is unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Haſt thou no reſpect for the family? Thou wilt bring endleſs diſgrace on the name of Rawbold. Shame on you! to take away from our reputation, when we have ſo little!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I thought, brother, you would have ſhewn more pity for your poor ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Tuſh! Love's a mere vapour.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Ah! brother.

sp.speaker: Barbara.
sp.l: From break of the morning, were I with my love,
I'd talk till the evening drew nigh;
And, when the day did cloſe,
I'd ſing him to repoſe,
And tune my love a lullaby.

sp.speaker: Samſon.
sp.l: From break of the morning, were I with my love,
O! long ere the evening drew nigh,
Her talk would make me doſe,
Till the muſick of my noſe
Would play my love a lullaby.

sp.speaker: Barbara.
sp.l: Our children around us, I'd look on my love,
Each moment in rapture would fly.

sp.speaker: Samſon.
sp.l: But love is apt to pall,
When the brats begin to ſquall,
And a wife is ſcreaming lullaby.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: From break of the mornings, &c,

div.head: SCENE II. A Room in Sir EDWARD MORTIMER's Lodge.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Sooth, you look better now; indeed you do.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Thou'rt a ſweet flatterer!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Ne'er truſt me, then,
If I do flatter. This is wilfulneſs.—
Thou wilt be ſick, becauſe thou wilt be ſick.
I'll laugh away this fancy, Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What couldſt thou do to laugh away my ſickneſs?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I'll mimick the phyſician—wiſe and dull—
With cane at noſe, and nod emphatical,
Portentous in my ſilence; feel your pulſe,
With an owl's face, that ſhall expreſs as much
As Galen's head, cut out in wood, and gilt,
Stuck over an apothecary's door.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: And what wouldſt thou preſcribe?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I would diſtil
Each flower that laviſh happineſs produced.
Through the world's paradiſe, ere Diſobedience
Scatter'd the ſeeds of care; then mingle each,
In one huge cup of comfort for thee, love,
To chaſe away thy dulneſs. Thou ſhouldſt wanton
Upon the wings of Time, and mock his flight,
As he ſail'd with thee tow'rd Eternity.
I'd have each hour, each minute of thy life,
A golden holiday; and ſhould a cloud
O'ercaſt thee, be it light as a goſſamer,
That Helen might diſperſe it with a breath,
And talk thee into ſunſhine!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Sweet, ſweet Helen!
Death, ſoften'd with thy voice, might dull his ſting,
And ſteep his darts in balſam. Oh! my Helen,
Theſe warnings which that griſly monarch ſends,
Forerunners of his certain viſitation,
Of late are frequent with me. It ſhould ſeem
I was not meant to live long.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Mortimer!
My Mortimer! You—Oh! for heaven's ſake,
Do not talk thus! You chill me. You are well;
Very well.—You give way—Oh, Mortimer!
Baniſh theſe fantaſies. Think on poor Helen!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Think on thee, Helen?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Aye: but not think thus.
You ſaid, my Mortimer, my voice could ſoothe,
In the moſt trying ſtruggle.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Said I ſo?
Yet, Helen, when my fancy paints a death-bed,
I ever place thee foremoſt in the ſcene,
To make the picture touching. After man
Is ſummon'd, and has made up his account,
Oh! 'tis a bitter after-reck'ning, when
His pallid lips receive the laſt, ſad kiſs,
Fond, female anguiſh prints! Then, Helen, then,
Then comes man's agony! To leave the object
He ſhelter'd in his heart, grief-ſtruck and helpleſs;
To graſp her hand; to fix his hollow eye
Upon her face, and mark her mute deſpair,
'Till the laſt flutter of his aching ſpirit
Hurri • s him hence, for ever!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh! for pity—
What have I done, that you— burſts into tears.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: My Helen!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I did not mean to weep. Oh, Mortimer,
I could not talk ſo cruelly to you!
I would not pain you thus, for worlds!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Nay, come;
I meant not this▪ I did not mean to ſay
There's danger now; but 'tis the privilege
Of ſickneſs to be grave, and moralize
On that which ſickneſs brings. I prithee, now,
Be comforted. Believe me, I ſhall mend.
I feel I ſhall already.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Do you, Mortimer?
Do you, indeed, feel ſo?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Indeed I do.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I knew you would:—I ſaid it. Did I not?
I'am ſo glad! You muſt be cautious now.—
I'll play the nurſe to-day—and then, to-morrow,
You ſhall not brood at home, as you are wont,
But we will ride together, through the foreſt.
You muſt have exerciſe. Oh! I will make you
Freſh as the ſummer dew-drop, and as healthy
As ruddy Labour, ſpringing from his bed,
To carol o'er the fallow!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Deareſt prattler!
Men would meet ſickneſs with a ſmiling welcome,
Were all woo'd back to health thus prettily.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I ſee it in your looks, now, you are better▪

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Scarce poſſible, ſo ſuddenly!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O, yes;
There is no little movement of your face
But I can mark on the inſtant—'Tis my ſtudy.
I have ſo gaz'd upon it, that, I think,
I can interpret ev'ry turn it has,
And read your inmoſt ſoul.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Mercy on me!
You change again.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: 'Twas nothing. Do not fear;
Theſe little ſhocks are uſual.—'Twill not laſt.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Would you could ſhake them off!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I would I could!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Reſolve it, then; and the bare reſolution
Will bring the remedy. Rally your ſpirits;
I prithee, now, endeavour.—This young man,
This boy—this Wilford—he has been ungrateful;
But do not let his baſeneſs wear you thus.
Ev'n let him go.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I'll hunt him through the world!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Why, look you there now! Pray be calm.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Well, well;
I am too boiſterous: 'Tis my unhappineſs
To ſeem moſt harſh where I would ſhew moſt kind.
The world has made me peeviſh. This ſame boy
Has ſomewhat moved me.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: He's beneath your care.
Seek him not now, to puniſh him. Poor wretch!
He carries that away, within his breaſt,
Which will embitter all his life to come,
And make him curſe the knowledge on't.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: The knowledge!—
Has he then breathed—Carries within his breaſt!
What does he know?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: His own ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: O, very true.

sp.speaker: Helen.
sp.l: Then leave him to his Conſcience.
It is a ſcorpion, ſent by Heaven itſelf,
To fix on hidden crimes; a flow, ſtill ſtream,
Of moulten lead, kept dropping on the heart,
To ſcald and weigh it down. Believe me, love,
There is no earthly puniſhment ſo great,
To ſcourge an evil act, as man's own conſcience,
To tell him he is guilty.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: 'Tis a hell!
I pray you talk no more on't.—I am weak—
I did not ſleep laſt night.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Would you ſleep now?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: No, Helen, no. I tire thy patient ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Tire me! nay, that you do not. You forget
How often I have ſat by you, and watch'd,
Fanning the buſy ſummer-flies away,
Leſt they ſhould break your ſlumbers. Who comes here?
What, Winterton! How do'ſt thou, old acquaintance?
How doſt thou, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Bleſs your goodneſs, well.
Is my good maſter better?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Somewhat, Adam.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Now, by our lady, I rejoice to hear it!
I have a meſſage—

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: O, no buſineſs now!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Nay, ſo I ſaid. Quoth I, his honour's ſick;
Perilous ſick! but the rogue preſs'd, and preſs'd;
I could refuſe no longer. Out upon them!
The varlets know old Winterton's good nature.
'Tis my weak ſide.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Who has thus importuned you?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: To ſay the truth, a moſt ill-favour'd varlet.
But he will ſpeak to none but to his worſhip.
I think 'tis foreſt buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, not now:
Another time—to-morrow—when he will.
I am unfit.—They teize me!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Ev'n as you pleaſe, your worſhip. I ſhould think,
From what he dropt, he can give ſome account
Of the poor boy.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Of Wilford!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Troth, I think ſo.
The knave is ſhy; but Adam has a head.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Quick; ſend him hither on the inſtant! Haſte!
Fly, Adam, fly!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Well now, it glads my heart
To hear you ſpeak ſo briſkly.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, diſpatch!

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: I go. Heaven bleſs you both! Heaven ſend you well,
And merry days may come again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I fear this buſineſs may diſtract you, Mortimer:
I would you would defer it till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Not ſo, ſweet. Do not fear. I prithee now,
Let me have way in this. Retire awhile.
Anon I'll come to thee.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Pray now, be careful.
I dread thoſe agitations. Pray, keep calm.
Now do not tarry long. Adieu, my Mortimer!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Farewel, awhile, ſweet!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Since it muſt be ſo—
Farewel!Exit Helen.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Dear, ſimple innocence! thy words of comfort
Pour oil upon my fires. Methought her eye,
When firſt ſhe ſpake of conſcience, ſhot a glance
Like her dead uncle on me. Well, for Wilford!
That ſlave can play the Parthian with my fame,
And wound it while he flies. Bring him before me,
Place me the runagate within my gripe,
And I will plant my honour on its baſe,
Firmer than adamant, tho' hell and death
Should moat the work with blood! Oh, how will ſin
Engender ſin! Throw guilt upon the ſoul,
And, like a rock daſh'd on the troubled lake,
'Twill form its circles, round ſucceeding round,
Each wider than the—
How now! What's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: Part with your office in the foreſt: part
Concerns yourſelf in private.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: How myſelf?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: Touching a ſervant of your houſe; a lad,
Whoſe heels, I find, were nimbler than his duty.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Speak; what of him? Quick—Know you where he is?
Canſt bring me to him?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: To the very ſpot.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Do it.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Nay, ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I'll reward you—amply—
Enſure your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: Firſt enſure my neck.
'Twill do me little good elſe. I've no heirs;
And, when I die, 'tis like the law will bury me,
At its own charge.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Be brief, and to your purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: Then, to the buſineſs which concerns your office,
Here, in the foreſt.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Nay, of that anon,
Firſt of my ſervant.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: Well, ev'n as you pleaſe.
'Tis no rare thing—Let public duty wait,
'Till private intereſts are ſettled▪ But
My ſtory is a chain. Take all together,
'Twill not unlink.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Be quick, then. While we talk,
This ſlave eſcapes me.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: Little fear of that.
He's in no plight to journey far to-day.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Where is he hid?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Hard by; with robbers.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Robber!—
Well, I'm glad on't. 'Twill ſuit my purpoſe beſt.
—What, has he turn'd to plunder?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: No; not ſo.
Plunder has turn'd to him. He was knock'd down,
Laſt night, here in the foreſt, flat and ſprawling;
And the milk-hearted captain of our gang
Has ſhelter'd him.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: It ſeems, then, thou'rt a thief?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: I ſerv'd in the profeſſion: But, laſt night,
The ſcurvy rogues caſhier'd me. 'Twas a plot,
To ruin a poof fellow in his calling,
And take away my means of getting bread.
I come here, in revenge. I'll hang my comrades,
In cluſters, on the foreſt oaks, like acorns.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Where lies their haunt?

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: Give me your honour, firſt—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I pledge it, for your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.l: Send your officers
To the old abbey ruins; you will find
As bold a gang as e'er infeſted woods,
And fatten'd upon pillage.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: What, ſo near me!
In ſome few minutes, then, he's mine! Ho! Wintetton!
Now for his lurking place! Hope dawns again.
Remain you here; I may have work for you.
O! I will weave a web ſo intricate,
For this baſe inſect! ſo entangle him!—
Why, Winterton!—Thou jewel, reputation!
Let me ſecure thee, bright and ſpotleſs, now;
And this weak, care-worn body's diſſolution,
Will cheaply pay the purchaſe! Winterton!Exit.

sp.speaker: Orſ.
sp.p: There may be danger in my ſtay here. I will e'en ſlink off, in the confuſion I have rais'd. I value not the reward. I hang my comrades, and that ſhall content me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Rare ſcuttling tow'rd! This lodge is little Babel:
And Spleen and Sickneſs are the houſehold gods,
In this, my brother's, caſtle of confuſion.
The hue and cry is up! I am half tempted
To wiſh the game too nimble for the dogs,
That hunt him at the hells. Diſhoneſt! Well,
I'll ne'er truſt looks again. His face hangs out
A goodly ſign; but all within, it ſeems,
Is dirty rooms, ſtale eggs, prick'd wine, ſour beer.
Rank bacon, muſty beef, and tallow candles.
I'll be deceived no more.—I'll mix with none,
In future but the ugly: honeſt men,
Who can out-grin a Griffin; or the head
Carved on the prow of the good ſhip the Gorgon.
I'm for carbuncled, weather-beaten faces,
That frighten little children, and might ſerve
For knockers to hall gates.—Now—who are you?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Head ſerving man to madam Helen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, I may talk to thee; for thou doſt anſwer
To the deſcription of the ſort of men
I have reſolved to live with.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.l: I am proud, Sir,
To find I have your countenance.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Can'ſt tell me
