The news of Wilford?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.l: He is turn'd a rogue, Sir,
An errant knave, Sir. 'Tis a rare thing, now,
To find an honeſt ſervant:—We are ſcarce.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Where lies the Abbey where they go to ſeek him?
Doſt know it?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.l: Marry, do I; in the dark.
I have ſtood near it, many a time, in winter,
To watch the hares▪ by moonlight.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: A cold paſtime!

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.p: Aye, Sir; 'twas killing work. I've left it off.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Think you they will be back ſoon?

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.l: On the inſtant:
It is hard by, Sir.—Hark I hear their horſes!
They are return'd, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Run you, fellow,—
If Wilford's taken, ſend him here to me.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.l: Why he's a rogue, Sir. Would your worſhip ſtoop
To parley with a rogue!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Friend, I will ſtoop
To prop a ſinking man, that's call'd a rogue,
And count him innocent, 'till he's found guilty.
I learn'd it from our Engliſh laws; where mercy
Models the weights that fill the ſcales of Juſtice,
And Charity, when Wiſdom gives her ſentence,
Stands by to prompt her. 'Till detection comes,
I ſide with the accuſed.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.l: Would I had known
Your worſhip ſooner. You're a friend, indeed!
All undiſcover'd rogues are bound to pray for you:
—So, Heaven bleſs you!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well, well—buſtle; ſtir:—
Do as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Samſ.
sp.l: Aye Sir.—I ſhall lean
Upon your worſhip in any time of need.—
Heaven reward you! —Here's a friend to make!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I have a kind of movement, ſtill, for Wilford,
I cannot conquer. What can be this charge
Sir Edward brings againſt him?—Should the boy
Prove guilty!—well; why ſhould I pity guilt?
Philoſophers would call me driv'ler.—Let them.
Whip a deſerter, and philoſophy
Stands by, and ſays he merits it. That's true:—
But wherefore ſhould philoſophy take ſnuff,
When the poor culprit writhes? A plague on ſtoicks!
I cannot hoop my heart about with iron,
Like an old beer-butt. I would have the veſſel
What ſome call weak:—I'd have it ooze a little.
Better compaſſion ſhould be ſet abroach,
'Till it run waſte, than let a ſyſtem-monger
Bung it with Logick; or a trencher cap
Bawl out his ethics on it, 'till his thunder
Turn all the liquor ſour.—So! Here he comes!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I am inform'd it is your pleaſure, Sir,
To ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye, Wilford. I am ſorry—
Faith, very ſorry,—you and I meet thus.
How could you quit my brother thus abruptly?
Was he unkind to you?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Moſt bountiful.
He made me all I am. The poor can number
His virtues thick as ſtars. I owe him, Sir,
A world of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: 'Tis a new mode
Of payment you have taken. Wherefore fly?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I was unfit to ſerve him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Unfit!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I was unhappy, Sir. I fled a houſe
Where certain miſery awaited me,
While I was doom'd to dwell in't.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Miſery!
What was this certain miſery?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Your pardon,—
I never will divulge.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: No, never.
Pray do not preſs me. All that I can ſay
Is, that I have a ſtrong, and rooted reaſon,
Which has reſolved me. 'Twere impoſſible
I ſhould be tranquil here. I feel it, Sir,
A duty to myſelf to quit this roof.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Harkye, young man. This ſmacks of myſtery;
And now looks foully. Truth, and Innocence,
Walk round the world in native nakedneſs.
But guilt is cloak'd.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Whate'er the prejudice
My conduct conjures up, I muſt ſubmit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: 'Twere better now you conjured up your friends:
For I muſt tell you—No, there is no need.
You learn'd it, doubtleſs, on the way, and know
The danger you, now, ſtand in.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Danger, Sir!
What? How? I have learn'd nothing, Sir; my guides
Drag'd me in ſilence hither.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Then 'tis fit
I put you on your guard. It grieves me, Wilford,
To ſay there is a heavy charge againſt you,
Which, as I gather, may affect your life.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Mine!—O, good Heaven!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Pray be calm:—for, ſoon,
Here, in the face of all his family,
My brother will accuſe you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: He!—What, He!
He accuſe me! O monſtrous! O, look down
You who can read mens hearts!—A charge againſt me!
Ha! ha! I'm innocent! I'm innocent!much agitatated

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Collect your firmneſs. You will need it all.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I ſhall, indeed! I pray you tell me, Sir,
What is the charge?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I do not know its purport.
I would not hear on't: for on my voice reſts
The iſſue of this buſineſs;—and a judge
Should come unbiaſs'd to his office. Wilford,
Were twenty brothers waiting my award,
You ſhould have even, and impartial juſtice.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: O, you are juſt! I would all men were ſo!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I hope moſt men are ſo. Rally your thoughts.
When you are call'd upon! if truth will ſerve you,
Sketch out your ſtory with her chaſte, bold pencil;
If truth ſhould fail you, Wilford, even take
The faireſt colour human art can mix,
To give a glow to plauſibility.
Tis ſelf-defence; and 'tis allow'd, when man
Muſt battle it, with all the world againſt him.
—Heaven bleſs you, boy!—that is, I mean— pſhaw! plague!
—Farewell! and may you proſper?Exit.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Then, all my youthful hopes are blighted in the bud! The breath of my powerful perſecutor will wither them. Let me recall my actions.—My breaſt is unclog'd with crime. This charge is to be open;—in the eye of the world; of the laws —Then, why ſhould I fear? I am native of a happy ſoil where juſtice guards equally the life of its pooreſt and richeſt inhabitant. Let him inflict his menaces upon me, in ſecret; Let him torture my mind and body; he ſhall not, cannot, touch my good name.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, Wilford!falls on his neck

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Barbara! at ſuch a time, too!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: To be brought back, thus, Wilford! and to go away without ſeeing me! without thinking of me!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: It was not ſo.—I was haſtening to your cottage, Barbara, when a ruffian, in the foreſt, encounter'd and wounded me.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Wounded you!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Be not alarm'd 'Tis not, as I thought yeſternight, of moment. One of his party took me to the Abbey ruins, and gave me timely ſuccour.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: And, was it ſo! was it ſo, Wilford?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Aye, Barbara. When I was drag'd hither, the whole troop eſcaped, or they had vouch'd for the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I would they had not eſcaped. For all here ſay that you had fled to join them.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What! join with robbers! what next ſhall I be charged with!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Bethink you, Wilford—the time is ſhort: I know your heart is good; but—
But what? Can you ſuſpect it, too, Barbara!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O! mine is ſo link'd with it, that I would follow you through beggary, through priſons, Wilford.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Priſon! The ſound, now, makes me ſhudder!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: If in a haſty moment you have done aught to wrong Sir Edward, throw yourſelf on his mercy; —ſue for pardon.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: For pardon!—I ſhall go mad! Pardon! I am innocent.—Heaven knows I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Heaven be thank'd!—The family is all ſummon'd. O, Wilford! my ſpirits ſink within me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: aſide I am, now, but a ſorry comforter. —Come, Barbara; be tranquil. You ſee I am ſo. Don't—don't you, Barbara?agitated

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You muſt attend in the next room.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: What, Walter, is it you? Pray tell me if—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Do not queſtion me. I hold no diſcourſe with any of your ſtamp.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Your tone is ſtrangely changed on the ſudden. What have I done?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You are going to be tried. That's enough for me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I might rather claim your pity on that ſcore, Walter.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What, pity a man that's going to be tried? O, monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Well, fare you well. I will not upbraid you, Walter. You have many in the world to countenance you. Blacken well your neighbour, and nine in ten are in haſte to cry ſhame upon him, ere he has time, or opoprtunity, to wipe off the accuſation. I follow you.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Do ſo. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p:
Be of good cheer. I go arm'd in honeſty, Barbara. I can bear every thing. Every thing, ſave
making you the partner of my misfortunes. That, Barbara—I am ſure you love me——That would give me a pang which would—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Alas! I tremble for his ſafety! ſhould they tear him from me!——

lg.l: DOWN by the river there grows a green willow;
Sing all for my true love! my true love, O!
I'll weep out the night there, the bank for my pillow;
And all for my true love, my true love, O!
When bleak blows the wind, and tempeſts are beating,
Ill count all the clouds, as I mark them retreating,
For true lovers joys, well a-day! are as fleeting.
Sing, O for my true love, &c.
Maids come, in pity, when I am departed;
Sing all for my true love, &c.
When dead, on the bank, I am found broken hearted,
And all for my true love, &c.
Make me a grave, all while the wind's blowing,
Cloſe to the ſtream, where my tears once were flowing,
And over my corſe keep the green willow growing.
'Tis all for my true love, &c.

div.stage: FITZ-HARDING, WILFORD, and various domeſticks, diſcovered.—To them enter ADAM WINTERTON.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Is not Sir Edward coming, Adam?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Aye, Sir.—
But he is grievous ill.—Since Wilford came,
He had another fit.—But he'll be here.
Ah, boy! that I ſhould live to ſee this day!
I have a merry heart no longer, now.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Good man! you have been ever kind to me.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: Heav'n ſend you may prove honeſt! Heav'n ſend it!
—Here comes Sir Edward. Would that I had died
Two reigns ago!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Now, brother.—You look pale,
And faint with ſickneſs.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: Here's a chair, your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: No matter.—To our buſineſs, brother Wilford,
You may well gueſs the ſtruggle I endure
To place you here the mark of accuſation.
I gave you ample warning: Caution'd you,
When many might have ſcourged: and, even now,
While I ſtand here to cruſh you,—aye, to cruſh you,—
My heart bleeds drops of pity for your youth,
Whoſe raſhneſs plucks the red deſtruction down,
And pulls the bolt upon you.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: You know beſt
The movements of your heart, ſir. Man is blind,
And cannot read them: but there is a Judge,
To whoſe all ſeeing eye our inmoſt thoughts
Lye open. Think to him you, now, appeal.—
Omniſcience keeps heaven's regiſter;
And, ſoon or late, when Time unfolds the book,
Our trembling ſouls muſt anſwer to the record,
And meet their due reward or puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Now, to the point, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Thus it is, then.
I do ſuſpect—By heaven the ſtory lingers,
Like poiſon, on my tongue,—but he will force it—

sp.speaker: Fitz
sp.p: What is it you ſuſpect?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: —That he has rob'd me.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Rob'd! I! O, horrible!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Not yet—not yet.
Pray tell me, brother—I will be impartial;—
But I am ſomewhat moved.—Pray tell me, brother,
How ground you this ſuſpicion!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Briefly, thus.——
You may have noticed, in my library,
A cheſt Wilford ſtarts—You ſee he changes at the word.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: And well I may!aſide.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Where I have told you, brother,
The writings which concern our family,
With jewels, caſh, and other articles,
Of no mean value, were depoſited.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: You oftentimes have ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Yeſterday,
Chance call'd me, ſuddenly away: I left
The key in't—but as ſuddenly return'd;
And found this Wilford, this young man, whoſe ſtate,
Whoſe orphan ſtate, met pity in my houſe,
'Till pity grew to friendſhip,—him I found,
Fix'd o'er the cheſt, upon his knees, intent,
As, now, I think, on plunder; tinging theft
Still blacker with ingratitude; and rifling
The eaſy fool who ſhelter'd him. Confuſion
Shook his young joints, as he let fall the lid,
And gave me back the key.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Did you not ſearch
Your papers on the inſtant?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: No:—for, firſt,
(Habit ſo long had fix'd my confidence)
I deem'd it boyiſh curioſity;—
But told him this would meet my further queſtion:
And, at that moment, came a ſervant in,
To ſay you were arrived. He muſt have mark'd
Our mix'd emotion.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Is that ſervant here?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: 'Twas I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Was it you? Well, ſaw you aught
To challenge your attention?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Sir, I did.
Wilford was pale and trembling; and our maſter
Gave him a look as if 'twould pierce him through;
And cried, "Remember."—Then he trembled more,
And we both quitted him.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: When firſt we met,
You found me ſomewhat ruffled.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: 'Tis moſt true.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: But ſomewhat more when, afterwards, I ſaw
Wilford converſing with you—like a ſnake,
Sun'd by your looks, and baſking in your favour.
I bade him quit the room, with indignation,
And wait my coming in the library.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: I witneſs'd that, with wonder.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, good brother!
You little thought, while you ſo gently ſchool'd me,
In the full flow of your benevolence,
For my harſh bearing tow'rd him, on what ground
That harſhneſs reſted. I had made my ſearch,
In the brief interval of abſence from you,
And found my property had vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: We'll—
You met him in the library?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O never
Can he forget that ſolemn interview!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Aye, ſpeak to that:—it was a ſolemn interview.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Obſerve, he does acknowledge that we met▪
Guilt was my theme:—he cannot now deny it.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: It was a theme of—No. checking himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: He pleaded innocence:
While every word he ſpake belied his features,
And mock'd his proteſtation. I reſtrain'd
The chaſtiſement he fear'd; nor wou'd I blazon
The wrong I could not fix; and ſubject, thus,
By general inquiry, all the guiltleſs
To foul ſuſpicion. That ſuſpicion lay
Moſt heavily on him; but the big cloud
Of anger he had gather'd burſt not on him,
In vengeance to o'erwhelm him: chill it drop'd,
But kindly, as the dew, in admonition;
Like tears of fathers o'er a wayward child,
When love enforces them to ruggedneſs.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: What ſaid you to him?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: "Regulate your life,
"In future, better. I, now, ſpare your youth;
"But dare not to proceed. All I exact,
"('Tis a ſoft penance)—that you tarry here,
"My eye your guard, my houſe your gentle priſon,
"My bounty be your chains. Attempt not flight;
"Flight ripens all my doubt to certainty,
"And juſtice to the world unlocks my tongue."—
He fled, and I arraign him.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Truſt me, brother,
This charge is ſtaggering. Yet accidents
Sometimes combine to caſt a ſhade of doubt
Upon the innocent. May it be ſo here!
Here is his trunk: 'twas brought here at my order.
'Tis fit that it be ſearch'd.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, that were needleſs.
He were a ſhallow villain that would truſt
His freight of plunder to ſo frail a bottom.
School-boys, who ſtrip the orchard of its fruit,
Conceal their thievery better.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Yet 'tis found,
Such negligence is often link'd with guilt.
—Take not—I ſay not yet that he is guilty,
But ſcarce heard of crafty villain, yet,
Who did not make ſome blot in his foul game,
That lookers-on have thought him blind, and mad,
It was ſo palpable.—'Tis rarely otherwiſe:
Heaven's hand is in it, brother: Providence
Marks guilt, as 'twere, with a fatuity.—
Adam, do you inſpect it. to Winterton.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Here's the key—
E'en take it, freely.—You'll find little there
I value; ſave a locket, which my mother
Gave me upon her death-bed; and ſhe added
Her bleſſing to't. Perhaps, her ſpirit now
Is grieving for my injuries.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: after opening the trunk. O, mercy!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: How now? What's there?

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.l: As I'm a wretched man,
The very watch my good old maſter wore!
And, here, my lady's jewels!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I am innocent.
Juſt Heaven hear me!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I muſt hear you, now.
What can you ſay?—Oh! Wilford.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Give me breath.
Let me collect myſelf. Firſt this. falls on his knees May ſleep
Ne'er cloſe my burning eyes; may conſcience gnaw me;
May engines wrench my entrails from their ſeat;
And whirl them to the winds before my face,
If I know aught of this!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Make it appear ſo.—But look there; look there!pointing to the trunk.

sp.speaker: Wilf
sp.l: Heap circumſtance upon me; multiply
Charge upon charge; pile ſeeming fact on fact;
Still I maintain my innocence. Look at me!
Are theſe the throes of guilt? Are theſe convulſions
Of a poor, helpleſs friendleſs, wretched boy,
The ſtruggles of a villain?—One thing more:
I here aver it—to his face aver it—
He knows—Yes, he—Yes, my accuſer knows,
I merit not his charge.

sp.speaker: Wint.
sp.p: O! fie on't, fie!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Wilford, take heed! A baſe attempt to blacken
An injured maſter, will but plunge you deeper.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I know what I am doing. I repeat it:
Will die repeating it. Sir Edward Mortimer
Is conſcious of my innocence.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Proceed—
Look at theſe proofs, and talk.—Unhappy boy,
Thy tongue can do me little miſchief now.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Do you not know—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: —'Tis no matter, ſir.
But I could ſwear—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Nay, Wilford, pauſe a while.
Reflect that oaths are ſacred. Weigh the for ••
Of theſe aſſeverations. Mark it well.
I ſwear by all the ties that bind a man,
Divine or human! Think on that, and ſhudder.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: The very words I utter'd! I am tongue-tied. aſide.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Wilford, if there be aught that you can urge,
To clear yourſelf, advance it.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: O, I could!
I could ſay much, but muſt not.—No, I will not.
Do as you pleaſe.—I have no friend—no witneſs,
Save my accuſer. Did he not—pray aſk him—
Did he not vaunt his wiles could ruin me?
Did he not menace, in his pride of power,
To blaſt my name, and cruſh my innocence?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: What do you anſwer, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: I anſwer—No.—
More were ſuperflous, when a criminal
Oppoſes empty volubility.
To circumſtantial charge. A ſtedfaſt brow
Repels not fact, nor can invalidate
Theſe dumb, but damning, witneſſes, before him.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: By the juſt Pow'r that rules us, I am ignorant
How they came there!—but 'tis my firm belief,
You placed them there, to ſink me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: O, too much!
You ſteel men's hearts againſt you! Death and ſhame!
It rouſes honeſt choler. Call the officers.—
He ſhall meet puniſhment. Servants going.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Hold! pray you, hold.
Juſtice has, thus far, ſtruggled with my pity,
To do an act of duty to the world.
I would unmaſk a hypocrite; lay bare
The front of guilt, that men may ſee and ſhun it:
'Tis done—And I will, now, proceed no further.
I would not hurt the ſerpent, but to make
The ſerpent hurtleſs. He has loſt his ſting.
Let him depart, and freely.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Lookye, brother.
This ſhall not be.—Had he proved innocent,
My friendſhip had been doubled; you well know
I have been partial to him—but this act
Is ſo begrimed with black, ungrateful malice,
That I inſiſt on juſtice. Fly, knaves! run,
And let him be ſecured. Exeunt ſervants. You tarry here to Wilford.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I will not have it thus.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: You muſt—You ſhall—
'Tis weak elſe. Oons! I truſt I have as much
Of good, ſtraight-forward pity, as may ſerve;
But, to turn dove—to ſit ſtill, and be peck'd at,
It is too tame. His inſolence tops all!
Does not this rouſe you, too?—Look on theſe jewels.—
Look at this picture.—'Twas our mother's: Stay,
Let me inſpect this nearer. What are here?
Parchments— inſpecting the trunk.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O, look no further.—They are deeds,
Which, in his haſte, no doubt he crowded there,
Not knowing what—to look o'er at his leiſure—
Family deeds—They all were in my cheſt.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: O, 'tis deep laid!—Theſe, too, to give a colour!aſide.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What have we here? I have your leave, good brother,
As arbiter in this. Here is a paper
Of curious enfolding—ſlipt, as 'twere
By chance, within another. This may be
Of note upon his trial.—What's this drops?
A knife, it ſeems!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What?ſtarting.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Marks of blood upon it.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Touch it not. Throw it back!—bury it— ſink it!
Oh, carele ••••… and haſte! Give me that paper.
Darkneſs and hell!—Give back the paper.

div.stage: MORTIMER attempts to ſnatch it; WILFORD runs between the two brothers, falls on his knees, and p • events him, holding FITZHARDING.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: rapidly No.
I ſee—I ſee!—Preſerve it. You are judge!—
My innocence, my life, reſts on it I

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Devils.
Foil me at my own game!—Fate!—Ha, ha, ha!
Sport, Lucifer!——He ſtruck me —

div.stage: MORTIMER is fainting, and falling; WILFORD runs and catches him.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: I'll ſupport him.——
Read! read! read!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What is this?—My mind miſgives me!
It is my brother's hand!—To die before me!
What can this mean?— reads.
Narrative of my murder of—Oh, great Heav'n!
"If by ſome chance my guilt ſhould be diſclos'd,
"May this contribute to redeem the wreck
"Of my loſt honour!"—I am horror-ſtruck!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: Plain! plain!—Stay! he revives.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: What has been—ſoft!
I have been wand'ring with the damn'd, ſure.— Brother!—
And—aye—'tis Wilford! Oh! thought flaſhes on me
Like Lightning. I am brain-ſcorch'd. Give me leave.
I will ſpeak—Soon I will—a little yet—
Come hither, boy.—Wrong'd boy! O Wilford, Wilford!

div.stage: burſts into tears, and falls on Wilford's neck.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.l: Be firm, Sir; pray be firm! my heart bleeds for you—
Warms for you! Oh! all your former charity
To your poor boy, is in my mind.—Still, ſtill,
I ſee my benefactor!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Well, I will—
I will be firm. One ſtruggle, and 'tis over.
I have moſt foully wrong'd you! Ere I die—
And I feel death-ſtruck—let me haſte to make
Atonement.—Brother, note. The jewels,
Yes, and that paper—Heaven and accident
Ordain'd it ſo!—were placed—Curſe on my fleſh,
To tremble thus!—were placed there by my hand.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: O, mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: More. I feared this boy;
He knew my ſecret; and I blacken'd him,
That, ſhould he e'er divulge the fatal ſtory,
His word might meet no credit. Infamy
Will brand my mem'ry for't: Poſterity,
Whoſe breath I made my god, will keep my ſhame
Green in her damning record. Oh! I had—
I had a heart o'erflowing with good thoughts
For all mankind! One fatal, fatal turn,
Has poiſon'd all! Where is my honour, now?
To die!—To have my aſhes trampled on,
By the proud foot of ſcorn! Polluted! Hell—
Who dares to mock my guilt? Is't you—or you?
—Wrack me that grinning fiend! Damnation!
Who ſpits upon my grave? I'll ſtab again—
I'll—Oh!falls.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: This rives my heart in twain. Why, brother, brother!
His looks are ghaſtly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the officers.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Away, knave! Send them hence—the boy is innocent.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What, Wilford?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye. Tell it your fellows. Hence!—
You ſhall know more anon. Send in ſome help—
Your maſter's ill o' the ſudden. Send ſome help!

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: 'Twere beſt to raiſe him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Soft, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Where is he? Ill! and on the ground! Oh, Mortimer!
Oh, Heaven! my Mortimer. O, raiſe him.— Gently.
Speak to me, love. He cannot!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Helen—'Twas I that——

div.stage: he ſtruggles to ſpeak, but appears unable to utter.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Oh, he's convulſed!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Say nothing. We muſt lead him to his chamber.
Beſeech you to ſay nothing! Come, good lady.

div.stage: FlTZHARDING and HELEN lead MORTIMER out.
Enter BARBARA, on the oppoſite ſide.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O, Wilford! I have flown to you! You are innocent.—The whole houſe now has it, you are innocent. Thank Heaven! Speak; tell me— How—how was it, dear, dear Wilford?

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p: I cannot tell you now, Barbara. Another time: But it is ſo.—I cannot ſpeak now.—

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Nor I, ſcarce, for joy! See! hither come your fellows, to greet you. I am ſo happy!

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Joy! Wilford.

sp.speaker: Wilf.
sp.p:
Peace, peace, I pray you. Our maſter is taken ill: So ill, my fellows, that I fear me he ſtands in much danger. That you rejoice in my acquittal, I perceive, and thank you. Sir Edward's brother will explain further to you: I cannot. But believe this:—Heaven, to whoſe eye the dark movements of guilt are manifeſt, will ever watch over,
and ſuccour the innocent, in their extremity. Clamour not now your congratulations to me, I entreat you: Rather, let the ſlow, ſtill voice of gratitude be lifted up to Providence, for that care ſhe ever beſtows upon thoſe deſerving her protection!

lg.l: Where Gratitude ſhall breathe the note,
To white-robed Mercy's throne,
Bid the mild ſtrain on aether float,
A ſoft and dulcet tone.
Sweet, ſweet and clear the accents raiſe,
While mellow flutes ſhall ſwell the ſong of praiſe,
Melody! Melody!
A ſoft and dulcet memory!
Where Fever droops his burning head;
Where ſick men languiſh on their bed;
Around let ev'ry accent be,
Harmony! Harmony!
A ſoft and dulcet harmony!
